greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of numbers m <= n that have a prime divisor greater than sqrt(n) (i.e., A006530(m)>sqrt(n)).
comment: Values of n that are squares of primes p^2 seem to reduce the value of a(p^2) from the value a(p^2 - 1). Example, a(24) = 13, a(25) = 9; a(120) = 70, a(121) = 60.
a(p^2) = a(p^2-1) - p + 1 if p is prime. If n is not the square of a prime, a(n) >= a(n-1).- _Robert Israel_, Aug 11 2014
link: Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5000
E. Naslund, The Average Largest Prime Factor, Integers, Vol. 13 (2013), A81. See "2. The Main Theorem."
formula: a(n) = Sum_{prime p > sqrt(n)} floor(n/p). - _Max Alekseyev_, Nov 14 2017
example: a(12) = 4, because there are four values of m = {5, 7, 10, 11} that have prime divisors that exceed sqrt(12) = 3.464... These prime divisors are {5, 7, 5, 11} respectively.
maple: N:= 1000: # to get a(1) to a(N)
program: (PARI) isok(i, n) = {my(f = factor(i)); my(sqrn = sqrt(n)); for (k=1, #f~, if ((p=f[k, 1]) && (p>sqrn) , return (1)););}
a(n) = sum(i=1, n, isok(i, n)); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Aug 11 2014
(PARI) A241419(n) = my(r=0); forprime(p=sqrtint(n)+1,n, r+=n\p); r; \\ _Max Alekseyev_, Nov 14 2017
results.author: _Michael De Vlieger_, Aug 08 2014
